About Me

Hello! My name is Max Bender and titles are weird, but if I were to give myself one it would be a Jr. Principal Engineer? While listening to a random episode of Arrested DevOps with Silvia Botros I heard this title that I had never heard before, a “Principal Engineer”. She explores it more in her blog post but the short of it is

“[being a Principal Engineer] is far more strategic, it’s far more business oriented, it’s involving a lot more influence, being an influencer without having the management title.”

“[during the time becoming a Principal Engineer you] need to be a force multiplier. There was a clear transition from me writing code to teaching others how to write code that’s actually clean and doesn’t cause us trouble too fast down the line. One of the big parts of Principal Engineering in my mind is you teach more than you actually do yourself.”

Why I call myself just a Jr. Principal Engineer is because there are a lot attributes of what Silvia talks about that I was already doing in my day to day job, but not quite at the same scale. I have a lot of experience to gain in being an influencer, but at IBM I feel like I fit the role of the force multiplier pretty well.

My job at IBM is to test software on Linux on Z and through that I got exposure to many technologies: Docker, Kubernetes, Ansible, Jenkins and Chef to name a few. This has been the perfect opportunity because I love to learn new things and have been told I have good knack at teaching what I have learned. Seeing that light bulb go off when explaining how to construct a Dockerfile, then using Travis to build that code via GitHub in regression is my favorite part of my job. closely followed by figuring out that bug that’s been plaguing me all week

Primarily, my work has been on CICD and DevOps solutions, but I often get this itch to create something new. Python is my go-to scripting language but I’m not afraid of a little Bash or Ruby if the use-case calls for it or I am trying to work with a library that requires the aforementioned (i.e Chef). The instant gratification of making websites and working with complex relational database setups is a puzzle that I relish. Using Flask and SQLAlchemy I have put together some complex websites as a consultant on the side. See the NexNest project as an example.

If I were to point to a shining accomplishment these past two years it was my port of Travis to the Mainframe. IBM has long been interested in enabling CICD and automation tools to be used by Open Source communities and internally to compile and test packages on s390x. Internally we can now build our packages in regression on the mainframe with Travis and hopefully soon the public will be able to too!

Projects

NexNest

github.com/maxbbender/nexnest

A Website made with love by @Max Bender and @Mike Mcginnis

I had written a couple website with Flask in school, but wanted to learn more and read up on Miguel Grinberg’s tutorial on Flask and was exposed to a new set of best practices. Approached with an idea for a rental website targeted at students we designed and implemented a website written in Python.

The website was backed by a fairly complex database that featured notifications and recursive comments. SQLAlchemy handles most of the direct SQL queries and more of the complex JOINs. See the implementation here https://github.com/maxbbender/nexnest/blob/master/docs/erd.pdf.

Travis on Z

github.com/bendermIBM/travis-cookbooks

Enable the tool that enables the tools on IBM's Mainframe

loreip

Experience

The Boring Company

boringcompany.com

Senior Network System Administrator

November 2017 - Present

Solving 21st century problems by diging holes and making game changing products like the *not a flamethrower*

Every company needs its networks properly administered and The Boring Compay is no exception. Digging holes is hard and I play my part making sure the whole company stays connected. I lead a team of 5 people and enjoy driving the company to try new technologies.

Education

Harvard University

BSc Computer Science

2010 - 2013

Established in 1636, Harvard is the oldest higher education institution in the United States, and is widely regarded in terms of its influence, reputation, and academic pedigree as a leading university in not just the US but also the world.

During my time at Harvard I learnt most of my key skills that have I have taken through my career such as teamwork and working to tight deadlines. I thouroughly enjoyed my time as university and learnt a lot about a healthy work life balance.

I spent a lot of my free time as a committee member of the Harvard Mountaineering Club taking on roles such as Trip Secretary and Vice-President.
